facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 350 of 1957 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 6, 1956 of the Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No.350 of 1957. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 6, 1956, of the Calcutta High Court on a numberice of motion in Appeal No. 152 of 1955.

facts.text: The High Court of Calcutta by order dated August 6, 1956 rejected the application of the appellant to be brought on record as appellant in Appeal No. 152 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENICATARAMA AIYAR J.-This is an appeal against an order of the High Court of Calcutta dated August 6, 1956, rejecting the application of the appellant to be brought on record as appellant in appeal No. 152 of 1955 pending before it.

facts.text: Sudhir Kumar Mitter was the owner of two houses No. 86/1 Cornwallis Street and No. 7-C Kirti Mitter Lane Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: The second respondent, Sudhir Kumar Mitter, was the owner of two houses, No. 86/1, Cornwallis Street and No. 7-C, Kirti Mitter Lane, Calcutta.

facts.text: On May 19, 1934 Sudhir Kumar Mitter executed a mortgage for Rs. 3,000 over the two houses in favour of Sm. Nirmala Sundari Dassi.

anchor.surface_text: On May 19, 1934, he executed a mortgage for Rs. 3,000 over the said houses in favour of the first respondent, Sm. Nirmala Sundari Dassi.

facts.text: Sm. Nirmala Sundari Dassi instituted Suit No. 158 of 1935 on the mortgage and obtained a preliminary decree on March 8, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: She instituted Suit No. 158 of 1935 on this mortgage, and obtained a pre- liminary decree on March 8, 1935.

facts.text: Registrar report dated July 23, 1935 found Rs. 3,914-6-6 due and final decree passed on April 20, 1936.

anchor.surface_text: The matter then came before the Registrar for taking of accounts, and by his report dated July 23, 1935 he found that a sum 1289 of Rs. 3,914-6-6 was due to her, and on that, a final decree was passed on April 20, 1936.

facts.text: First respondent took no steps to have the decree drawn up for nearly 18 years.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent who had acted with such alacrity and speed in putting her mortgage in suit and obtaining a decree, took numbersteps whatsoever to have the decree drawn up, for nearly 18 years.

facts.text: On May 12, 1952 the second respondent sold both houses to the appellant for Rs. 60,000 utilised largely for discharging prior mortgages and deed recites sold free of all encumbrances.

anchor.surface_text: On May 12, 1952, the second respondent sold both the houses to the appellant herein for a sum of Rs. 60,000 which was, it is stated, utilised largely for discharging prior mortgages on which decrees had been obtained and execution proceedings taken. The deed of sale recites that the properties were sold free of all encumbrances.

facts.text: On February 17, 1954 first respondent obtained ex parte order under r. 27 to draw up and complete the decree.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent who had so far taken numbersteps to have the decree drawn up number bestirred herself, and on February 17, 1954 obtained an ex parte order under r. 27 aforesaid, granting her leave to draw up and companylete the decree.

facts.text: On April 29, 1954 first respondent filed the final decree and commenced proceedings for sale of the mortgaged properties.

anchor.surface_text: That having been done pursuant to the order, she filed on April 29, 1954 the final decree, and companymenced proceedings for sale of the mortgaged properties.

facts.text: Second respondent objected that execution of the decree was barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: Coming to know of this, the second respondent appeared before the Registrar, and raised the objection that the execution of the decree was barred by limitation.

facts.text: P. B. Mukharji J held that execution of the decree was not barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: The matter then came before P. B. Mukharji J. and after hearing 1290 companynsel for both the respondents, he held that the execution of the decree was number barred.

facts.text: Second respondent preferred Appeal No. 152 of 1955 against the judgment which is still pending.

anchor.surface_text: Vide judgment reported in Nirmala Sundari v. Sudhir Kumar  1 . Against this judgment, the second respondent preferred Appeal No. 152 of 1955, and that is still pending.

facts.text: On July 25, 1956 the appellant applied to be brought on record as appellant in Appeal No. 152 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: We number companye to the application, out of which the present appeal arises. On July 25, 1956 the appellant applied to be brought on record as appellant in Appeal No. 152 of 1955.

facts.text: Appellant alleged purchase free of encumbrances execution proceedings not maintainable as time-barred second respondent conducted proceedings at her instance now collusive.

anchor.surface_text: The allegations in support of the petition were that she had purchased the properties from the second respondent on May 12, 1952 free of all encumbrances, that the execution proceedings started by the first respondent were number maintainable as the decree had become time-barred, that the second respondent, Sudhir Kumar Mitter, had been companyducting proceedings in opposition to the execution sale only at her instance and for her benefit, that he had filed Appeal No. 152 of 1955 also oil her behalf, that latterly he had entered into a companylusive arrangement with the first respondent with a view to defeat her rights

facts.text: Respondents stated they entered into arrangement settling amount due at Rs. 17,670 fair bona fide binding on appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The application was strenuously opposed by both the respondents. They stated that they had entered into an arrangement settling the amount due to the first respondent at Rs. 17,670, that that settlement was fair and bona fide and binding on the appellant

facts.text: Chakravarti C.J. and Lahiri J. dismissed the application by order dated August 6, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: This application was heard by Chakravarti C. J. and Lahiri J. and by their order dated August 6, 1956, they dismissed it.

facts.text: Appellant applied under Art. 133 for leave to appeal to Supreme Court which was rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied under Art. 133 for leave to appeal to this Court, and in rejecting that application, the learned Chief Justice observed that the original application was pressed only under 0. 22, r. 10 of the Civil Procedure Code and it was dismissed

facts.text: Appellant obtained special leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter obtained special leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution, and that is how the appeal companyes before us.

facts.text: In affidavit dated December 20, 1956 on behalf of first respondent particulars given for Rs. 17,670 including Rs. 7,200 interest at contract rate Rs. 5,000 costs in other suits Rs. 1,750 costs in proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: In the affidavit of Sanjit Kumar Ghose dated December 20, 1956, filed on behalf of the first respondent, particulars are given as to how the sum of Rs. 17,670 was made up. It will be seen therefrom that a sum of Rs. 7,200 is claimed for interest up to March 8, 1956, calculating it number at the rate provided in the final decree but at the companytract rate. Then a sum of Rs. 5,000 is included as for companyts incurred by the mortgagee in suits other than ... A sum of Rs. 1,750 is agreed to be paid for companyts in the sale reference

facts.text: Appellant contends amount recoverable under decree will not exceed Rs. 6,000.

anchor.surface_text: But it is stated for the appellant that under the decree which is sought to be executed the amount recoverable for principal and interest will number exceed Rs. 6,000.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside the order dated August 6, 1956 and directed appellant be brought on record as additional appellant in Appeal No. 152 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly set aside the order of the Court below dated August 6, 1956 and direct that the appellant be brought on record as additional appellant in Appeal No. 152 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: It is contended OD behalf of the appellant that her application is maintainable under 0. 22, r. 10 of the Civil Procedure Code, because Suit No. 158 of 1935 must be considered to have been pending until the decree therein was drawn up which was in 1954, and the transfer in her favour had been made prior thereto on May 12, 1952.

arguments.claim: Application falls within Section 146 CPC entitling appellant to be brought on record

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the application filed by the appellant falls within s. 146 of the Civil Procedure Code, and she is entitled to be brought on record under that section. Section 146 provides that save as otherwise provided by the Code, any proceeding which can be taken by a person may also be taken by any person claiming under him.

B. Mukharji J. she not having done so was not entitled to be brought on record as an appellant to continue the appeal preferred by the second respondent.

holdings.text: The appellant's application is not maintainable under O. 22, r. 10 of the Civil Procedure Code as no application was made in the original court during pendency of the suit and the transfer was not made during pendency of the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Nor could the application made to the appellate Court be sustained under 0. 22, r. 10, as the transfer in favour of the appellant was made prior to the filing of that appeal and not during its pendency. This contention appears to be well-founded but that, however, does not conclude the matter.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Respondent's contention accepted: no prior application in trial court and transfer predates appeal filing; O.22 r.10 inapplicable to appellate stage without pendency during appeal.

holdings.text: The application filed by the appellant falls within s. 146 of the Civil Procedure Code, and she is entitled to be brought on record under that section.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the application filed by the appellant falls within s. 146 of the Civil Procedure Code, and she is entitled to be brought on record under that section. Section 146 provides that save as otherwise provided by the Code, any proceeding which can be taken by a person may also be taken by any person claiming under him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.146 allows any person claiming under another to take any proceeding; appeal is a proceeding; 'claiming under' includes assignment/devolution per precedents like Sitharamaswami and Jugalkishore Saraf.

holdings.text: S. 146 CPC is not to be construed narrowly to authorise only initiation of proceedings but also continuation of an appeal filed by the transferor.

anchor.surface_text: We are not disposed to construe s. 146 narrowly in the manner contended for by counsel for the first respondent. That section was introduced for the first time in the Civil Procedure Code, 1908 with the object of facilitating the exercise of rights by persons in whom they come to be vested by devolution or assignment, and being a beneficent provision should be construed liberally

holdings.reasoning_summary: Beneficent provision to be construed liberally to advance justice; right to file appeal includes right to continue existing appeal by transferor; cites Muthiah Chettiar allowing continuation of execution.

holdings.text: The petition of the appellant to be brought on record as an appellant in Appeal No. 152 of 1955 must be held to be maintainable under s. 146.

anchor.surface_text: The right to file an appeal must therefore be held to carry with it the right to continue an appeal which had been filed by the person under whom the applicant claims, and the petition of the appellant to be brought on record as an appellant in Appeal No. 152 of 1955 must be held to be maintainable under s. 146.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combines prior holdings on s.146 applicability to appeals and continuation; assignee entitled despite not filing own appeal.

holdings.text: On the merits, there should be an order in favour of the appellant as substantial questions exist warranting her participation.

anchor.surface_text: It remains to consider whether, on the merits, there should be an order in favour of the appellant. Of that, we have no doubt whatsoever. The proceedings in which she seeks to intervene arise in execution of a mortgage decree. She has purchased the properties comprised in the decree for Rs. 60,000 under a covenant that they are free from encumbrances.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purchaser for value free of encumbrances; execution after 18 years; disputes on limitation and amount due (Rs.6000 vs Rs.17670 with improper inclusions); vital interest as purchaser pendente lite bound by outcome; justice requires opportunity to protect rights.

holdings.text: As a purchaser pendente lite, the appellant will be bound by the proceedings and justice requires that she should be given an opportunity to protect her rights.

anchor.surface_text: It is obvious that there are several substantial questions arising for determination in which the appellant as purchaser of the properties is vitally interested, and indeed is the only person interested. As a purchaser pendente lite, she will be bound by the proceedings taken by the first respondent in execution of her decree, and justice requires that she should be given an opportunity to protect her rights.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Doctrine of purchaser pendente lite binds buyer to proceedings; equity demands locus to intervene given stakes.

holdings.text: The order of the High Court dated August 6, 1956 is set aside and the appellant is directed to be brought on record as additional appellant in Appeal No. 152 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly set aside the order of the Court below dated August 6, 1956 and direct that the appellant be brought on record as additional appellant in Appeal No. 152 of 1955. As Sudhir Kumar Mitter, the appellant not on record, has dropped the fight with the first respondent, we conceive that no embarrassment will result in there being on record two appellants with Conflicting interest.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of prior holdings and merits; no prejudice from additional appellant given second respondent's acquiescence.

anchor.surface_text: Nor could the application made to the appellate Court be sustained under 0. 22, r. 10, as the transfer in favour of the appellant was made prior to the filing of that appeal and not during its pendency. This contention appears to be well-founded but that, however, does not conclude the matter.
We accordingly set aside the order of the Court below dated August 6, 1956 and direct that the appellant be brought on record as additional appellant in Appeal No. 152 of 1955.

edges.explanation: Holding h2 affirmatively holds that the application falls within s. 146 CPC, directly addressing issue i2.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the application filed by the appellant falls within s. 146 of the Civil Procedure Code, and she is entitled to be brought on record under that section. Section 146 provides that save as otherwise provided by the Code, any proceeding which can be taken by a person may also be taken by any person claiming under him.
We accordingly set aside the order of the Court below dated August 6, 1956 and direct that the appellant be brought on record as additional appellant in Appeal No. 152 of 1955.

edges.explanation: Holding h3 rejects narrow construction of s. 146, addressing issue i3.

anchor.surface_text: We are not disposed to construe s. 146 narrowly in the manner contended for by counsel for the first respondent. That section was introduced for the first time in the Civil Procedure Code, 1908 with the object of facilitating the exercise of rights by persons in whom they come to be vested by devolution or assignment, and being a beneficent provision should be construed liberally
We accordingly set aside the order of the Court below dated August 6, 1956 and direct that the appellant be brought on record as additional appellant in Appeal No. 152 of 1955.
We accordingly set aside the order of the Court below dated August 6, 1956 and direct that the appellant be brought on record as additional appellant in Appeal No. 152 of 1955.

edges.explanation: Holding h5 that there should be an order in favour of appellant on merits directly addresses issue i4

anchor.surface_text: It remains to consider whether, on the merits, there should be an order in favour of the appellant. Of that, we have no doubt whatsoever. The proceedings in which she seeks to intervene arise in execution of a mortgage decree. She has purchased the properties comprised in the decree for Rs. 60,000 under a covenant that they are free from encumbrances.
We accordingly set aside the order of the Court below dated August 6, 1956 and direct that the appellant be brought on record as additional appellant in Appeal No. 152 of 1955.

edges.explanation: Holding h6 elaborates the justice in giving opportunity to purchaser pendente lite, supporting the merits-based order in h5.
Holding h6 providing opportunity to appellant relates to whether order in her favour on merits under i4

anchor.surface_text: It is obvious that there are several substantial questions arising for determination in which the appellant as purchaser of the properties is vitally interested, and indeed is the only person interested. As a purchaser pendente lite, she will be bound by the proceedings taken by the first respondent in execution of her decree, and justice requires that she should be given an opportunity to protect her rights.
We accordingly set aside the order of the Court below dated August 6, 1956 and direct that the appellant be brought on record as additional appellant in Appeal No. 152 of 1955.
We accordingly set aside the order of the Court below dated August 6, 1956 and direct that the appellant be brought on record as additional appellant in Appeal No. 152 of 1955.
